structured_notes.meeting_objective: To brainstorm and define the scope of a new beginner-friendly fitness app, including its features, target audience, business model, and technical stack.
key_discussion_points: Defining the target audience as fitness beginners rather than hardcore athletes.
Identifying core features: workout tracking, pre-made plans, exercise demos, and progress visualization.
Discussing a simplified nutrition tracking method using photos and AI analysis instead of manual calorie counting.
Exploring monetization through a freemium model with a premium subscription.
Outlining the proposed technology stack: React Native, Node.js, PostgreSQL, and AWS.
Estimating the project timeline and budget for development.
Debating the scope of social features and integrations for the initial version.
pain_points: Difficulty competing with large companies like Apple in the fitness space.
High cost and infrastructure requirements for hosting video content.
The nutrition tracking market is already saturated with established apps like MyFitnessPal.
Potential inaccuracy of AI for food photo analysis.
Risks associated with social features, including the need for moderation and privacy controls.
Concern that the initial 6-month development timeline might be too aggressive.
requirements: Exercise demonstrations (images/GIFs or linked videos for MVP).
Meal photo tracking with AI analysis.
Progress visualization and tracking (e.g., photos, weight).
Basic social sharing features (private sharing with friends).
Integration with Apple Health and Google Fit.
decisions_made: The app will target fitness beginners aged 25-45 who feel intimidated by other apps.
For the MVP, exercise demonstrations will use images/GIFs or link to external videos to avoid hosting costs.
Nutrition tracking will be based on meal photos analyzed by a third-party AI API.
Social features will be limited to private progress sharing in V1.
The business model will be freemium, with a premium subscription at $9.99/month or $79.99/year.
The tech stack will be React Native for mobile, Node.js for the backend, and hosted on AWS.
The app will be mobile-first, with no web version planned for the initial launch.
The development timeline is set to 6-8 months.
action_items: Sarah will create a formal Product Requirements Document (PRD) based on the discussion for review in the next meeting.
technical_constraints: Video hosting costs are a constraint, leading to the decision to use images/GIFs or external links for MVP.
The app will rely on existing third-party APIs for food recognition (e.g., Google Cloud Vision API).
React Native will be used to manage a single codebase for both iOS and Android.
Initial integrations will be limited to Apple Health and Google Fit, excluding others like Strava for V1.
